Engine: 1,045 cc (63.8 cu in) single-cylinder 1.1 kW (1.5 PS; 1.5 bhp)
Comment: First production car

Engine: 3,442 cc (210.0 cu in) inline-6 119 kW (162 PS; 160 hp)
Comment: Some publications cite the XK120's timed top speed as almost 214 km/h (133 mph) in 1949.[6] The XK120 that achieved this speed had a tonneau over the passenger seat and an aero screen fitted. When in completely standard form, the car reached 200.5 km/h (124.6 mph) when tested by Motor.

Engine: 2,996 cc (182.8 cu in) inline-6 158 kW (215 PS; 212 hp)
Comment: Two-way average speed tested by Automobil Revue in 1958. 245 km/h (152.2 mph) reached in one direction.

Engine: 3,670 cc (224 cu in) inline-6 225 kW (306 PS; 302 hp)
Comment: Tested by Autosport in December 1961.

Engine: 3,670 cc (224 cu in) inline-6 234 kW (318 PS; 314 hp)
Comment: Tested by Autocar in April 1962.
Tested by Autocar in 1966. A total of 412 Iso Grifos were built 1963–1974.[11]
Tested by Car & Driver. Top speed described as observed.
Tested by Motor in June 1967. Over 750 units built in 1966–1973 period, which includes P400, P400 S and P400 SV models.
Tested by Autocar in 1971.
Tested by Sport Auto in 1970.
Tested by Auto, Motor und Sport.

Engine: 3,367 cc (205.5 cu in) turbocharged flat-6 275 kW (374 PS; 369 hp)
Comment: Tested by Auto, Motor und Sport, about 20-30 built with Ruf VIN.

Engine: 2,849 cc (173.9 cu in) twin-turbocharged flat-6 331 kW (450 PS; 444 hp)
Comment: Tested by Road & Track in 1987. The 959 Deluxe version attained 317 km/h (197 mph), the Sport version 319 km/h (198 mph). 29 were built in a performance-enhanced 379 kW (508 hp; 515 PS) sports version which reached 339 km/h (211 mph) tested by Auto, Motor und Sport at Nardo in 1988.[20][21]

Engine: 3,367 cc (205.5 cu in) twin-turbocharged flat-6 345 kW (469 PS; 463 hp)
Comment: Tested by Auto, Motor und Sport at Nardò Ring in 1988.

Some publications cite the F1's timed top speed as 240.1 mph (386.4 km/h). This speed was achieved by a modified F1 with the rev limiter raised from 7500 rpm to 8300 rpm, not a production car.[23] The F1 in an unmodified state is gear limited at 221 mph (356 km/h).

Engine: 2,994 cc (182.7 cu in) twin-turbocharged flat-6 537 kW (730 PS; 720 hp)
Comment: Independently measured at Ehra-Lessien in November 1998.[26]

Engine: 7,993 cc (487.8 cu in) quad-turbocharged W16 736 kW (1,001 PS; 987 hp)
Comment: Recorded and verified by German inspection officials on 19 April 2005.[28]

Engine: 6,345 cc (387.2 cu in) twin-turbocharged V8 882 kW (1,200 PS; 1,183 hp)
Comment: Inspected and verified by Guinness World Records on 9 October 2007.

Engine: 7,993 cc (487.8 cu in) quad-turbocharged W16 882 kW (1,200 PS; 1,183 hp)
Comment: Out of the initial production run of 30 cars, 5 were named the Super Sport World Record Edition, which had the same electronic limiter as the other 25 – but turned off. Pierre-Henri Raphanel drove the unlimited Super Sport World Record Edition to a 431.072 km/h (267.856 mph) two-way average, verified by Guinness World Records.[31][32][33] When sold, the electronic limiters were re-activated, limiting them to the same 415 km/h (258 mph) as the entire production run.

Engine: 5,000 cc (310 cu in) twin-turbocharged V8 1,000 kW (1,360 PS; 1,341 hp)
Comment: The base engine is rated at 865 kW (1,176 PS; 1,160 hp), 11 cars were factory specced with the 1 MW (1,360 PS; 1,341 hp) option. Niklas Lilja drove the 1 MW Agera RS to a top speed of 447.19 km/h (277.87 mph), independently verified by Racelogic.[34][35][36][37][38][39]

Engine: 5,900 cc (360 cu in) twin-turbocharged V8 1,300 kW (1,770 PS; 1,750 hp) when on E85 fuel
Comment:
When on regular fuel, has 1,007 kW (1,369 PS; 1,350 hp).
It achieved the top speed on 17 January 2021.[40]
